They push numbers over the quality of care of their clients. Can be a very discouraging environment overall and more so for women who are serious about their recovery.

review_title: Mixed bag. This company has potential, but needs to make major changes.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Most of staff seem to have their hearts in the right place and genuinely want to help the community.
-Inclusive and diverse staffing. Nothing is perfect, and it can always be better, but you can tell leadership tries in this area.
-Many cases of great care provided here when patients are compliant and high functioning enough. 
-Good place to learn medicine and nursing in a relatively low-stakes environment. If you make a mistake, nobody will drop dead. There's no open-heart surgery going on. 
-Lots of internal promotions. High performers are recognized and promoted rapidly. 
-Leadership seems to be as transparent as they can be and offers updates regularly. 
-Fairly good educational opportunities. There are paid educational days and paid continuing education credits. If you apply yourself, you will learn a lot. Clinical staff is helpful and eager to share knowledge and advice.
-There are staff meetings where feedback and opinions from staff are encouraged. Some of the ideas are great and are implemented.
-Steady supply of PPE. Always felt safe against COVID.
-Encouraged to take PTO and not shamed when you need sick days. If you don't use all of your PTO there is pay out when you leave.
-Good medical, vision, and dental benefits
cons:
-A supposed non-profit that claims "Healthcare is a Right, Not a privilege" yet maintains unrealistic productivity goals and blames staff when requirements are not met. It was painful to be part of. 
-Extremely frugal company that does not pay well, but at the same time pays some staff too well and is often out of medical supplies. 
 -Most of clinical staff and management are new graduates. They cannot attract staff with more experience because the pay is so low. Many of these people are smart and you can see their potential, but they lack professional and life experience.
-High turnover of clinical staff and management, so there is limited institutional knowledge and constant on-boarding.
-Reports of abuse from staff by patients are taken seriously, and sometimes these patients are put on cool-off periods. Other times, action is not taken quickly enough and the patient returns only to be hostile again. There needs to be quicker action.
-Out of touch executive team that operates from an ivory tower. Most are non-medical and do not understand the daily grind. 
-Limited resources overall and even the new building needs improvement. The toilet floods often . Hope that got fixed, it's 2022. The ancient Romans are laughing in their graves.
-There was an actual bona fide Ellen DeGenerous caliber psychopath employed there at one point. It was terrifying and stressful, but also strangely captivating, like watching a python slither through the office. What will it do next?!

job_title: EMT-B in Santa Clara, CA
pros: I felt that healthright360 was a quality company and was happy to work for them

job_title: Front Desk in San Francisco, CA
pros: Staff were for the most part extremely dedicated and compassionate, despite lack of support & resources. Most of them were the best co-workers I've ever had, hands-down. The clinic does excellent & vital work for the community, especially for transgender patients, who are especially vulnerable & have had to deal with discrimination and mistreatment in medical settings.
cons:
Disappointing benefits. Chronically understaffed, and staff is overworked. I thought this was a short term issue, but it is an ever-worsening default state.  Burnout is very common. Management is out-of-touch, unsupportive, and can be downright adversarial to employees, which is really unfortunate. For example, not replacing staff who left, and then (management) putting increasing pressure on the remaining employees to finish the work of 2+ people without the time or staff to do so.  The staff at LMHS are already overworked, and yet they're treated as though they just aren't working hard enough. Very blaming / shaming environment, which is extra undermining when the job itself is so taxing, emotionally and intellectually. Staff has been without mid-level management for nearly a year. 
Despite being a loyal and hard worker, I was fired, and then HR360 tried to deny my unemployment (I won on appeal). It was devastating to be fired from a job that I cared about so deeply. I'm also very disappointed that I put so much of my heart and mind into that job, and yet I was treated so poorly by upper management.

review_title: Mixed ratings among employees and consumers alike
job_title: Client Care Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: The integrated health-services model according to which this non-profit organization operates attracts and employs many highly skilled and caring people in direct-services positions across health disciplines. Many of HealthRight's patients, clients, and facility residents are people who use drugs, and people in recovery. The delivery of appropriate services for clients and patients with complex needs is attended to conscientiously by direct-service professionals. Over the past two years, front-line workers have organized and formed a strong union, a process that has enhanced the sense of community among workers.
cons: The organization itself is under persistent pressure to perform according to a patient-services model that is dictated by the austerity measures that have been levied on community safety-net clinics because federal spending on healthcare has been so embattled amid the weighty fiscal changes that have emerged in recent years. State regulations limit Medicaid's reimbursement rate and many services are not covered, resulting in heavy reliance on grants and contracts. There is a high turnover rate at all levels of the organization, and the tendency is for the vacated positions to be eliminated rather than filled. Upper-middle managers rely on suppressive tactics to exert influence, rather than through positive reinforcement-- promotions are rare, as are raises in wages for non-management employees. Although the front-line workers have gained ground in forming a union, the COVID-19 pandemic has delayed the bargaining process, so the workforce represented has yet to negotiate a contract as of 9/1/2020.

job_title: Physician Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Amazing coworkers and good support
cons: High stress environment, complex patients

job_title: Residential Counselor in Escondido, CA
pros: Diversity, ability to make a difference
cons: Employees don't always feel appreciated

job_title: Counselor in San Francisco, CA
pros: You'll learn a lot on the job and really help clients - no thanks to HealthRIGHT 360, but to the nature of the job and the true need of the clients. You'll thrive if you do well with sink or swim.
cons:
Poor pay, almost laughable. The majority of senior management is grossly unqualified for their roles and barely know what really goes down in the field, though confidence can get you far. While some departments are run by people who are qualified (i.e. medical or psychiatric, probably because those are audited), most got their positions because they were in the right place at the right time and rolled with it.

If you are an ethnic minority, you will find yourself surrounded by white senior management and corporate staff. You'll occasionally hear them talk big game about diversity and inclusion, but it's never going to happen at the top. A minority token, maybe. Lot of people who think they're "woke" but are just enjoying making more money than everyone down below.

Senior management and corporate suite don't care about their employees unless they need something out of them (press, marketing, a favor), and it's telling of how things work around here.

High staff turnover to the point where workload can become nearly impossible. Also results in a lot of recent grads getting hired who have no clue what re-entry and homelessness looks like until they're in here.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you are passionate about the mission and have the drive and desire, there is support and encouragement to grow. Most IT staff have been with the organization for several years. There is good camaraderie and little drama. I am in a different role now, but I was proud to identify as part of the IT Dept, as it is respected and influential within the organization. Although the IT Dept. does not work directly with clients in the same way counselors do, it was satisfying to see how technology, reports, and data can impact services, funding, best practices, and people's lives.
cons: If you are looking for a situation where you can coast, tune out, or expect a corporate IT salary, it is not a good fit.

review_title: Great team (especially IT) working to help marginalized individuals
job_title: Director of Research in San Francisco, CA
pros: I worked with senior management for more than 4 years and I truly believe that they care about the clients they serve. I have never met a more dedicated or intelligent  group of leaders. The IT department, in particular, is working to build a strong team and doing so by fostering trust and communication among senior leaders to model for everyone in the department. They continue these practices in the face of mergers and the constant change associated with non-profit environments.
cons: It is a large agency and, inevitably, some individuals will have had negative experiences. I have no doubt that there are some under-staffed programs or over-worked clinicians. I also know that they care and work incredibly hard every day to provide the most they can to those they serve, so I try to view those situations in context.

review_title: Organization doesn’t value its employees, burnout is inevitable and quick
job_title: Clinic Staff in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-You will work with other equally passionate people 
- You will gain so much knowledge just by way of interacting with the clients and the different moving parts of this organization 
- You will most definitely grow, even if it is by way of “sink or swim”. 
- You will get to see first hand the impact of the work you are doing with different client populations
cons:
- Management is often not present
- Severe lack of any sort of structure for on-boarding employees 
- High turnover due to burnout 
- Basic tools/organizational structure needed to succeed not provided 
- Lack of framework is unsustainable and quickly leads to burnout

review_title: AARS Santa Clara County provides caring work place

cons: - Fast paced - so be ready to jump in!

review_title: Good experience, but overworked and underpaid

review_title: Lots of work with no support and no pay

cons: Dealing with mounds of paperwork and not having time to actually provide clients with enough help and support to make an impact. You ever complain to HR about an employee of racial color or of some status in the company and they will run you out of your job. You won't get paid for the time you work either, you will have deadlines that are unrealistic and you will have to work off the clock to meet the deadlines or be written up. So they will get free work from you as well.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: As another reviewer mentioned, this is a  great place to gain experience and opportunities to learn.
cons:
San Francisco mental health workers have to input mandatory documentation twice into Welligent (company based) and Avatar (SF based) software. There's redundancy and that should be resolved to save time and frustration.  
The staff from acquired agencies feel like just a number.
Short staffed in some programs.

review_title: Where service providers come to jump ship
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
1. You are able to make a direct impact in the lives of clients - from one on one interactions, groups, more.
2. The clients are fantastic; they make you realize that they are the reason you do social work. The perseverance, will, and commitment to change and growth is real. They might struggle at times, but they are only human.
3. The teammates - fellow staff are in the same boat and are incredibly supportive.
4. Really, the work, impact, and experiences that you make are incredible.
cons:
1. PAY IS NOT COMPETITIVE. HealthRIGHT 360 provides decent pay at the administrative level, but laughable, unlivable wages at the service level. Annual raises are just as laughable.
2. Upper management is not transparent to "lower level" staff or clients. We have no idea where the funding comes from, where the clients' funds actually go, or how many things are managed. It's an odd mystery that makes both staff and clients wonder.
3. No room for movement - there are only so positions one can move up to if not away from service provision. 
4. High turnover; as this is a company that is both high stress and thrives off of recent graduates (many of whom are willing to work for low wages), there is very high turnover.
5. With #4 in mind, service positions are high stress with little support as far as employee needs for self care.
6. PTO and sick days are combined.
7. Politics - with these mergers, you notice that newly merged partners typically have many replaced staff who settle for lower pay grades.
8. Inconsistent harm reduction policy in the residential facilities - some are still very much "old school" to a fault
9. Not ALL staff are up to date regarding basic things - EMR system, computers, current mental health/substance abuse treatment methods... It's a tad discouraging.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pomona, CA
pros: Working full-time 40 hours a week and guaranteed to work 40 hours a week and you get a steady paycheck. You will work holidays too if that is what you desire. You will gain experience in working in teams and what it is really like to work on a team and you will find out what it means to multi-task if you never did it before and you will learn the job quickly - within 3 weeks. Learned many new things that I never did before. Love working with clients and infants.
cons: If you are not a smoker, you will find yourself not taking your (2) 10 min breaks since there is so much work to be done. The smokers will expect you to do something when they are on their smoke break. Communication is not a top priority between team members and company culture is very laid back (almost too laid back to where staff are doing their own thing and you are left wondering what is going on). Sometimes you will be asked to do things from your coworkers - that may not be in your job description and things that your supervisor has not cleared for you to do. Busy busy busy busy. Many others have heavy caseloads and tons of paper work. Seems 9 hours is not enough time in the day. No career opportunities if you have a business degree. Limited career opportunities if you have a 2 year degree or have a substance abuse certificate. Pay is very very low, but this is non-profit. All nonprofits are the same. They don't pay well. Ever. You may work holidays and no see your family since the center never closes.

job_title: Infectious Diseases Program Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Improving the lives of marginalized underinsured homeless populations dealing with substance use and mental disorders, and providing primary care services.  Working with post incarceration clients assisting with navigation of re-entry services.
cons: Dynamic funding streams which affect salaries and determine capacity and resources.  Proficiency/efficiency expectations associated with increased productivity and performance management equates to higher work loads with less emphasis placed on employee satisfaction.
